title: The Moment That Changed Everything

content: I didn’t know if I was going to live or die. And I didn't care. I was numb and had no hope left.
I was 15 years old, abandoned by my father at 14, bounced around group homes, and landed in the hospital with my organs shutting down five months shy of my 16th birthday.
The only person who came to see me in the hospital was a woman I’d worked for over the summer. Her name was Shannon Wentworth.
The doctor pulled her aside and told her, “If you don’t take her, she will go to a group home and she will die.” And that was it for her.
A 34-year-old lesbian, no kids, not married, decided to take me in and spend the next three years of her life saving mine. In March 2007. I went to live with her.

I hadn’t been on antivirals for a year and half at this point because the side effects were debilitating and the meds were barely keeping me alive. So I decided to stop the meds and live as long as I could without being miserable.

content: Shortly after Shannon took me in, I got shingles. They were all over the right side of my neck and began traveling to my face. Excruciating pain I wouldn't wish on anyone. After we got my shingles under control and she became my legal guardian, Shannon got to work.

She enrolled me in a clinical trial for a new HIV medication that was supposed to completely control the virus, allowing me to live a long, normal life. What they called being undetectable. This sounded promising, but I’d heard it all at this point. I wasn’t impressed. I was tired of taking medicine and I had PTSD from the side effects.
I’d have rather died than go through it again.

But for the first time in my life I was being loved unconditionally. Shannon refused to give up on me despite my pushback. She told me I wouldn’t have to go to school through the side effects and she’d stay by my side as long as it took me to put the pills in my mouth.

content: I told her I’d take the meds under one condition: I could get my bellybutton pierced. And so we had an agreement. When I become undetectable, I can get my piercing.

She prepared me by creating little pill pockets and putting my favorite candies in them, giving them to me twice daily to get me used to a schedule again. She even wrote little notes and poems on them to make it fun. After a couple of weeks, it was time for the real deal.
She brought me my meds morning and night. The first two weeks, I was so sick. I was hallucinating and feeling nauseous. I could barely sleep or get out of bed.

Some days, it took her hours to get the pills in my mouth. She sat by my side while I cried, pleaded, and begged to die. She continued to tell me how loved I am, how worthy I am of life, and that my suffering wouldn’t last forever. That the rainbow was just on the other side. That I can do it.

content: She made me feel so loved and so wanted. A feeling I yearned for my whole life.

After the side effects subsided, I was able to go back to everyday living. Shannon continued to give my meds in homemade pill pockets with cute notes, and I focused on my belly piercing. Three months passed and I was feeling healthy. I don't have much to compare feeling healthy to, but I felt good.
On Aug. 12, 2007, a month after I turned 16, my world changed forever. I’m going to share a journal entry I wrote that day:

“Ok, so Friday night me and my best friend were in the bathtub (with bathing suits) at my mom’s girlfriend’s house in Calistoga. Then they started banging on the door and ran in. With so much excitement they said, “GUESS WHAT!?” I said “what!?” They said, “we just got a call from your doctor and you’re ZERROOOOO!!!!”

I am undetectable!! Can you believe it? It’s incredible. I’ve never in my life thought I would actually be at this point. I don’t have AIDS anymore and they can't find the HIV virus in my system… Yay! So because I’m zero, my mom took me to Zebras and I got my bellybutton pierced… I am sooo happy! If it wasn’t for my mom (Shannon) and her support and help, I wouldn’t be at this point in life…”

content: That was the day I became undetectable! And I’ve been undetectable since. Almost 18 years now. Shannon literally saved my life. Wow. That was the day I found out I was going to live. My feelings were indescribable. And day by day I became more confident in my new reality and I had hope. A literal dream came true.

Although I’m not cured of HIV, I feel being undetectable is just as good as being cured. I get to live, not pass it, and have babies. Facing death for almost 16 years, losing my birth mom to HIV, and then being able to LIVE was all I'd ever dreamed of.

I’m happy and grateful we reached this advancement and people today don’t have to live with the thought of premature death by HIV. What a time to be alive. And I can’t wait for the day HIV is eradicated completely by a medical cure, or better yet, everyone getting on meds and no longer passing the virus. We can achieve this faster than waiting for a cure.

content: If you’d like more information on what undetectable means and how to achieve it, please see my previous blog post, "Undetectable and How to Get There." For insight on how far we’ve come, read my blog post “How HIV is Different Today Than When I Was Diagnosed at Age 2.”

If you’re newly diagnosed, let this be an inspiration to your journey and how successful you can be taking your new meds. Minimal to no side effects (what a dream) and getting control of the virus doesn’t take long.
HIV doesn’t have to hold you back in any way. Please don’t let it. Utilize the many resources that are available. You got this!
